title: Navigating First Trimester Worries
subtitle: It's normal to feel anxious - you're not alone

main_content.introduction: The first trimester can feel like an emotional rollercoaster. Between the physical symptoms, hormonal changes, and the weight of this life-changing news, it's completely normal to feel overwhelmed, anxious, or uncertain at times.
validation_statements: Your worries don't make you a bad parent - they make you a caring one
Feeling anxious about pregnancy is one of the most normal human responses
Every pregnant person worries - you're in excellent company
Anxiety often comes from love and the deep desire for everything to be okay

coping_strategies.description: Learn enough to feel informed, but avoid information overload. Choose one or two trusted sources rather than endless googling.
coping_strategies.action: Set specific times for pregnancy research rather than constant searching.

coping_strategies.description: When worry spirals start, bring yourself back to the present moment. Focus on what you can control right now.
coping_strategies.action: Try the 5-4-3-2-1 technique: name 5 things you can see, 4 you can touch, 3 you can hear, 2 you can smell, 1 you can taste.

coping_strategies.description: Share your worries with trusted people. Anxiety often loses power when spoken aloud to someone who cares.
coping_strategies.action: Identify 2-3 people you can talk to honestly about your pregnancy concerns.

coping_strategies.description: Your healthcare provider has heard every worry before. Don't hesitate to call with questions or concerns.
coping_strategies.action: Write down questions between appointments so you remember to ask them.

when_to_seek_help: If anxiety is interfering with sleep, eating, or daily activities
If you're having panic attacks or persistent intrusive thoughts
If worry is preventing you from taking care of yourself
If you feel hopeless or overwhelmed most of the time

partner_guidance.title: How Partners Can Help
suggestions: Listen without trying to fix - sometimes she just needs to voice her worries
Help with practical tasks to reduce overall stress
Attend appointments when possible for shared reassurance
Encourage professional help if anxiety seems overwhelming

family_sharing_guidance.what_to_share: It's okay to tell trusted family members that you're feeling anxious - they can provide support
family_sharing_guidance.boundaries: You don't need to share every worry with everyone - choose your confidants wisely
family_sharing_guidance.asking_for_help: Let family know specific ways they can support you during this time

cultural_adaptations.universal_themes: Worry as expression of love, community support during vulnerable times
cultural_adaptations.cultural_considerations: Some cultures have specific practices for managing pregnancy anxiety - incorporate what feels meaningful to you
